    Highlights

    •
    CCT2 regulates aggrephagy via associating with ATG8s and aggregation-prone proteins
    •
    CCT2 functions independently of ubiquitin-binding autophagy receptors
    •
    CCT2 enables autophagy-mediated clearance of solid protein aggregates
    •
    CCT2 monomer formation acts as a switch of function from chaperone to autophagy

    Summary

    Protein aggregation is a hallmark of multiple human pathologies. Autophagy selectively degrades protein aggregates via aggrephagy. How selectivity is achieved has been elusive. Here, we identify the chaperonin subunit CCT2 as an autophagy receptor regulating the clearance of aggregation-prone proteins in the cell and the mouse brain. CCT2 associates with aggregation-prone proteins independent of cargo ubiquitination and interacts with autophagosome marker ATG8s through a non-classical VLIR motif. In addition, CCT2 regulates aggrephagy independently of the ubiquitin-binding receptors (P62, NBR1, and TAX1BP1) or chaperone-mediated autophagy. Unlike P62, NBR1, and TAX1BP1, which facilitate the clearance of protein condensates with liquidity, CCT2 specifically promotes the autophagic degradation of protein aggregates with little liquidity (solid aggregates). Furthermore, aggregation-prone protein accumulation induces the functional switch of CCT2 from a chaperone subunit to an autophagy receptor by promoting CCT2 monomer formation, which exposes the VLIR to ATG8s interaction and, therefore, enables the autophagic function.

    Introduction

    Accumulation of protein aggregates is a hallmark of multiple human pathologies, including neurodegeneration, eye disease, and type II diabetes (Mathieu et al., 2020
    62.
    Mathieu, C. ∙ Pappu, R.V. ∙ Taylor, J.P.
    Beyond aggregation: pathological phase transitions in neurodegenerative disease
    Science. 2020; 370:56-60
    Google Scholar
    ; Valastyan and Lindquist, 2014
    101.
    Valastyan, J.S. ∙ Lindquist, S.
    Mechanisms of protein-folding diseases at a glance
    Dis. Model. Mech. 2014; 7:9-14
    Google Scholar
    ; Vaquer-Alicea and Diamond, 2019
    103.
    Vaquer-Alicea, J. ∙ Diamond, M.I.
    Propagation of protein aggregation in neurodegenerative diseases
    Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2019; 88:785-810
    Google Scholar
    ). Sufficient amounts of evidence demonstrate autophagy, a lysosome-mediated bulk degradation pathway, as a key cellular process to clear protein aggregates (Lamark and Johansen, 2012
    51.
    Lamark, T. ∙ Johansen, T.
    Aggrephagy: selective disposal of protein aggregates by macroautophagy
    Int. J. Cell Biol. 2012; 2012:736905
    Google Scholar
    ). How the autophagic membrane recognizes protein aggregates and selectively targets them for degradation has been a major question in the field. Multiple studies show that ubiquitin-binding receptors (P62(SQSTM1), NBR1, TAX1BP1, Optineurin, and Tollip) (Kirkin et al., 2009
    44.
    Kirkin, V. ∙ Lamark, T. ∙ Sou, Y.S. ...
    A role for NBR1 in autophagosomal degradation of ubiquitinated substrates
    Mol. Cell. 2009; 33:505-516
    Google Scholar
    ; Korac et al., 2013
    48.
    Korac, J. ∙ Schaeffer, V. ∙ Kovacevic, I. ...
    Ubiquitin-independent function of optineurin in autophagic clearance of protein aggregates
    J. Cell Sci. 2013; 126:580-592
    Google Scholar
    ; Lu et al., 2014
    61.
    Lu, K. ∙ Psakhye, I. ∙ Jentsch, S.
    Autophagic clearance of polyQ proteins mediated by ubiquitin-Atg8 adaptors of the conserved CUET protein family
    Cell. 2014; 158:549-563
    Google Scholar
    ; Pankiv et al., 2007
    75.
    Pankiv, S. ∙ Clausen, T.H. ∙ Lamark, T. ...
    p62/SQSTM1 binds directly to Atg8/LC3 to facilitate degradation of ubiquitinated protein aggregates by autophagy
    J. Biol. Chem. 2007; 282:24131-24145
    Google Scholar
    ; Sarraf et al., 2020
    84.
    Sarraf, S.A. ∙ Shah, H.V. ∙ Kanfer, G. ...
    Loss of TAX1BP1-directed autophagy results in protein aggregate accumulation in the brain
    Mol. Cell. 2020; 80:779-795.e10
    Google Scholar
    ), the cytosolic proteins containing both a ubiquitin-binding domain and an LC3-interacting region (LIR, allowing for the binding of autophagy-related protein 8s (ATG8s) on the autophagic membrane), are responsible for recruitment of the autophagic membrane to protein aggregates and, therefore, mediate the autophagic clearance (Gatica et al., 2018
    19.
    Gatica, D. ∙ Lahiri, V. ∙ Klionsky, D.J.
    Cargo recognition and degradation by selective autophagy
    Nat. Cell Biol. 2018; 20:233-242
    Google Scholar
    ; Johansen and Lamark, 2020
    37.
    Johansen, T. ∙ Lamark, T.
    Selective autophagy: ATG8 family proteins, LIR motifs and cargo receptors
    J. Mol. Biol. 2020; 432:80-103
    Google Scholar
    ; Khaminets et al., 2016
    40.
    Khaminets, A. ∙ Behl, C. ∙ Dikic, I.
    Ubiquitin-dependent and independent signals in selective autophagy
    Trends Cell Biol. 2016; 26:6-16
    Google Scholar
    ). Because the nature of these ubiquitin-binding receptors is to recognize ubiquitin chains, they are usually not specific for aggrephagy and mostly shared by other types of selective autophagy, e.g., mitophagy, xenophagy, and lysophagy (Gatica et al., 2018
    19.
    Gatica, D. ∙ Lahiri, V. ∙ Klionsky, D.J.
    Cargo recognition and degradation by selective autophagy
    Nat. Cell Biol. 2018; 20:233-242
    Google Scholar
    ; Khaminets et al., 2016
    40.
    Khaminets, A. ∙ Behl, C. ∙ Dikic, I.
    Ubiquitin-dependent and independent signals in selective autophagy
    Trends Cell Biol. 2016; 26:6-16
    Google Scholar
    ).
    Recent studies have identified another category of autophagy receptors (e.g., FUNDC1, NIX, and BNIP3) in mitophagy (Hanna et al., 2012
    27.
    Hanna, R.A. ∙ Quinsay, M.N. ∙ Orogo, A.M. ...
    Microtubule-associated protein 1 light chain 3 (LC3) interacts with Bnip3 protein to selectively remove endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria via autophagy
    J. Biol. Chem. 2012; 287:19094-19104
    Google Scholar
    ; Liu et al., 2012

    Liu, L. ∙ Feng, D. ∙ Chen, G. ...

    Nat. Cell Biol. 2012; 14:177-185
    Google Scholar
    ; Novak et al., 2010

    Novak, I. ∙ Kirkin, V. ∙ McEwan, D.G. ...
    Nix is a selective autophagy receptor for mitochondrial clearance
    EMBO Rep. 2010; 11:45-51
    Google Scholar
    ) and FAM134B, TEX264, Atg39, and Atg40 (yeast) in ER-phagy (An et al., 2019
    3.
    An, H. ∙ Ordureau, A. ∙ Paulo, J.A. ...
    TEX264 is an endoplasmic reticulum-resident ATG8-interacting protein critical for ER remodeling during nutrient stress
    Mol. Cell. 2019; 74:891-908.e10
    Google Scholar
    ; Khaminets et al., 2015
    41.
    Khaminets, A. ∙ Heinrich, T. ∙ Mari, M. ...
    Regulation of endoplasmic reticulum turnover by selective autophagy
    Nature. 2015; 522:354-358
    Google Scholar
    ; Mochida et al., 2015
    69.
    Mochida, K. ∙ Oikawa, Y. ∙ Kimura, Y. ...
    Receptor-mediated selective autophagy degrades the endoplasmic reticulum and the nucleus
    Nature. 2015; 522:359-362
    Google Scholar
    ). Unlike the ubiquitin-binding receptors mentioned above, these receptors do not harbor a ubiquitin-binding domain but are LIR-containing organelle-resident proteins that are specific organelle markers unique for each type of selective autophagy (Chino and Mizushima, 2020
    12.
    Chino, H. ∙ Mizushima, N.
    ER-phagy: quality control and turnover of endoplasmic reticulum
    Trends Cell Biol. 2020; 30:384-398
    Google Scholar

    Cell Res. 2014; 24:787-795
    Google Scholar
    ). Although specific aggrephagy receptors have been reported in yeast S. cerevisiae (Atg19, cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting [Cvt] pathway) and C. elegans (SEPA-1 and EPG-7) (Lin et al., 2013
    56.
    Lin, L. ∙ Yang, P. ∙ Huang, X. ...
    The scaffold protein EPG-7 links cargo–receptor complexes with the autophagic assembly machinery
    J. Cell Biol. 2013; 201:113-129
    Google Scholar
    ; Scott et al., 2001
    88.

    ; Zhang et al., 2009

    SEPA-1 mediates the specific recognition and degradation of P granule components by autophagy in C. elegans
    Cell. 2009; 136:308-321
    Google Scholar
    ), it has been unclear whether specific aggrephagy receptors exist in mammals and, if they exist, how they regulate aggrephagy.
    Emerging evidence indicates phase separation as an important phenomenon involved in multiple cellular processes and human diseases (Alberti and Dormann, 2019
    2.
    Alberti, S. ∙ Dormann, D.
    Liquid-liquid phase separation in disease
    Annu. Rev. Genet. 2019; 53:171-194
    Google Scholar
    ; Banani et al., 2017
    5.
    Banani, S.F. ∙ Lee, H.O. ∙ Hyman, A.A. ...
    Biomolecular condensates: organizers of cellular biochemistry
    Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2017; 18:285-298
    Google Scholar
    ; Hyman et al., 2014
    33.
    Hyman, A.A. ∙ Weber, C.A. ∙ Jülicher, F.
    Liquid-liquid phase separation in biology
    Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 2014; 30:39-58
    Google Scholar
    ; Shin and Brangwynne, 2017
    91.
    Shin, Y. ∙ Brangwynne, C.P.
    Liquid phase condensation in cell physiology and disease
    Science. 2017; 357:eaaf4382
    Google Scholar
    ). It has been shown that aggregation-prone proteins form phase-separated biomolecular condensates/droplets before transitioning into pathogenic solid protein aggregates (Babinchak and Surewicz, 2020
    4.
    Babinchak, W.M. ∙ Surewicz, W.K.
    Liquid-liquid phase separation and its mechanistic role in pathological protein aggregation
    J. Mol. Biol. 2020; 432:1910-1925
    Google Scholar
    ; Mathieu et al., 2020
    62.
    Mathieu, C. ∙ Pappu, R.V. ∙ Taylor, J.P.
    Beyond aggregation: pathological phase transitions in neurodegenerative disease
    Science. 2020; 370:56-60
    Google Scholar
    ; Patel et al., 2015
    76.
    Patel, A. ∙ Lee, H.O. ∙ Jawerth, L. ...
    A liquid-to-solid phase transition of the ALS protein FUS accelerated by disease mutation
    Cell. 2015; 162:1066-1077
    Google Scholar
    ; Ray et al., 2020
    82.
    Ray, S. ∙ Singh, N. ∙ Kumar, R. ...
    α-Synuclein aggregation nucleates through liquid-liquid phase separation
    Nat. Chem. 2020; 12:705-716
    Google Scholar
    ; Wegmann et al., 2018
    110.
    Wegmann, S. ∙ Eftekharzadeh, B. ∙ Tepper, K. ...
    Tau protein liquid-liquid phase separation can initiate tau aggregation
    EMBO J. 2018; 37:e98049
    Google Scholar
    ). Autophagy has been proposed to preferentially clear protein condensates with a certain amount of liquidity using the known aggrephagy receptors Atg19 (S. cerevisiae) or SEPA-1 (C. elegans) (Yamasaki et al., 2020
    116.
    Yamasaki, A. ∙ Alam, J.M. ∙ Noshiro, D. ...
    Liquidity is a critical determinant for selective autophagy of protein condensates
    Mol. Cell. 2020; 77:1163-1175.e9
    Google Scholar
    ; Zhang et al., 2018
    122.
    Zhang, G. ∙ Wang, Z. ∙ Du, Z. ...
    mTOR regulates phase separation of PGL granules to modulate their autophagic degradation
    Cell. 2018; 174:1492-1506.e22
    e1422
    Google Scholar
    ). In addition, the ubiquitin-binding receptors, P62 and NBR1, organize the formation of phase-separated condensates, which likely facilitates autophagic clearance of the protein condensates (Agudo-Canalejo et al., 2021
    1.
    Agudo-Canalejo, J. ∙ Schultz, S.W. ∙ Chino, H. ...
    Wetting regulates autophagy of phase-separated compartments and the cytosol
    Nature. 2021; 591:142-146
    Google Scholar
    ; Sun et al., 2018
    95.
    Sun, D. ∙ Wu, R. ∙ Zheng, J. ...
    Polyubiquitin chain-induced p62 phase separation drives autophagic cargo segregation
    Cell Res. 2018; 28:405-415
    Google Scholar
    ; Turco et al., 2021
    100.
    Turco, E. ∙ Savova, A. ∙ Gere, F. ...

    Nat. Commun. 2021; 12:5212
    Google Scholar
    ; Zaffagnini et al., 2018
    119.
    Zaffagnini, G. ∙ Savova, A. ∙ Danieli, A. ...
    p62 filaments capture and present ubiquitinated cargos for autophagy
    EMBO J. 2018; 37:e98308
    Google Scholar
    ). However, it remains to be clarified how solid protein aggregates are recognized and selectively cleared by aggrephagy.
    Cellular proteostasis is tightly controlled by a network of molecular chaperones that maintain protein folding and cooperate with the degradation machinery (Hipp et al., 2019
    29.
    Hipp, M.S. ∙ Kasturi, P. ∙ Hartl, F.U.
    The proteostasis network and its decline in ageing
    Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2019; 20:421-435
    Google Scholar
    ; Kim et al., 2013
    42.
    Kim, Y.E. ∙ Hipp, M.S. ∙ Bracher, A. ...
    Molecular chaperone functions in protein folding and proteostasis
    Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2013; 82:323-355
    Google Scholar
    ). Chaperones counteract aberrant folding and aggregation via direct binding to the misfolded protein (Hipp et al., 2019
    29.
    Hipp, M.S. ∙ Kasturi, P. ∙ Hartl, F.U.
    The proteostasis network and its decline in ageing
    Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2019; 20:421-435
    Google Scholar
    ; Kim et al., 2013
    42.
    Kim, Y.E. ∙ Hipp, M.S. ∙ Bracher, A. ...
    Molecular chaperone functions in protein folding and proteostasis
    Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2013; 82:323-355
    Google Scholar
    ). Chaperonins are among the earliest types of chaperones identified (Horwich and Fenton, 2020
    32.
    Horwich, A.L. ∙ Fenton, W.A.
    Chaperonin-assisted protein folding: a chronologue
    Q. Rev. Biophys. 2020; 53:e4
    Google Scholar
    ). The eukaryotic chaperonin TCP-1 ring complex (TRiC) accounts for the folding of ∼10% of cytosolic protein substrates, including cytoskeletal proteins, cell cycle regulators, and aggregation-prone proteins (Gestaut et al., 2019
    21.
    Gestaut, D. ∙ Limatola, A. ∙ Joachimiak, L. ...
    The ATP-powered gymnastics of TRiC/CCT: an asymmetric protein folding machine with a symmetric origin story
    Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2019; 55:50-58
    Google Scholar
    ; Jin et al., 2019
    36.
    Jin, M. ∙ Liu, C. ∙ Han, W. ...
    TRiC/CCT chaperonin: structure and function
    Subcell. Biochem. 2019; 93:625-654
    Google Scholar
    ). The TRiC consists of eight subunits (CCT1-8) arranged in two octameric rings stacked back to back. Each subunit consists of an equatorial domain and an apical domain that are responsible for ATP and substrate binding, respectively. Protein folding is achieved through a coordinated ATP-driven conformational cycle (Gestaut et al., 2019
    21.
    Gestaut, D. ∙ Limatola, A. ∙ Joachimiak, L. ...
    The ATP-powered gymnastics of TRiC/CCT: an asymmetric protein folding machine with a symmetric origin story
    Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2019; 55:50-58
    Google Scholar
    ; Jin et al., 2019
    36.
    Jin, M. ∙ Liu, C. ∙ Han, W. ...
    TRiC/CCT chaperonin: structure and function
    Subcell. Biochem. 2019; 93:625-654
    Google Scholar
    ). Subunits of chaperonin TRiC were found to be components of protein aggregates or associating with aggregation-prone proteins (David et al., 2010
    13.
    David, D.C. ∙ Ollikainen, N. ∙ Trinidad, J.C. ...
    Widespread protein aggregation as an inherent part of aging in C. elegans
    PLoS Biol. 2010; 8:e1000450
    Google Scholar
    ; Kim et al., 2016
    43.
    Kim, Y.E. ∙ Hosp, F. ∙ Frottin, F. ...
    Soluble oligomers of PolyQ-expanded huntingtin target a multiplicity of key cellular factors
    Mol. Cell. 2016; 63:951-964
    Google Scholar
    ). Although multiple studies have shown that the TRiC and its subunits prevent protein aggregate formation (Behrends et al., 2006
    6.
    Behrends, C. ∙ Langer, C.A. ∙ Boteva, R. ...
    Chaperonin TRiC promotes the assembly of polyQ expansion proteins into nontoxic oligomers
    Mol. Cell. 2006; 23:887-897
    Google Scholar
    ; Kitamura et al., 2006
    45.
    Kitamura, A. ∙ Kubota, H. ∙ Pack, C.G. ...
    Cytosolic chaperonin prevents polyglutamine toxicity with altering the aggregation state
    Nat. Cell Biol. 2006; 8:1163-1170
    Google Scholar
    ; Noormohammadi et al., 2016
    73.
    Noormohammadi, A. ∙ Khodakarami, A. ∙ Gutierrez-Garcia, R. ...
    Somatic increase of CCT8 mimics proteostasis of human pluripotent stem cells and extends C. elegans lifespan
    Nat. Commun. 2016; 7:13649
    Google Scholar
    ; Tam et al., 2006
    97.
    Tam, S. ∙ Geller, R. ∙ Spiess, C. ...
    The chaperonin TRiC controls polyglutamine aggregation and toxicity through subunit-specific interactions
    Nat. Cell Biol. 2006; 8:1155-1162
    Google Scholar
    ), it has been unclear whether these aggregate-associated TRiC subunits have extra functions in maintaining proteostasis.
    In the current work, we identify a function of the TRiC subunit chaperonin-containing TCP-1 subunit 2 (CCT2) in aggrephagy, which is conserved in mammals and yeast. CCT2 promotes autophagosome incorporation and clearance of protein aggregates with little liquidity via interacting with ATG8s and aggregation-prone proteins independent of cargo ubiquitination. In addition, CCT2 acts independently of the known lysosome-mediated pathways for clearance of aggregation-prone proteins; e.g., ubiquitin-binding receptors (P62, NBR1, and TAX1BP1)-mediated aggrephagy and chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA). CCT2 switches its function from a chaperone to an autophagy receptor via monomer formation, which exposes its ATG8-interaction motif and, therefore, allows for the recruitment of autophagosomal membranes. The dual function of CCT2, as a chaperone and an aggrephagy receptor, enables double-layer maintenance of proteostasis.

    Results

    Identification of CCT2, a chaperonin subunit responsible for LC3 targeting to inclusion bodies

    Selective targeting of the autophagic membrane to protein aggregates is an essential step in aggrephagy (Gatica et al., 2018
    19.
    Gatica, D. ∙ Lahiri, V. ∙ Klionsky, D.J.
    Cargo recognition and degradation by selective autophagy
    Nat. Cell Biol. 2018; 20:233-242
    Google Scholar
    ). To dissect this process, we developed an in vitro reconstitution system to recapitulate autophagic membrane targeting to protein aggregates (Figure 1A). It has been shown that autophagy receptors recruit autophagic membranes via associating with the ATG8 family members on the autophagosome (Johansen and Lamark, 2020
    37.
    Johansen, T. ∙ Lamark, T.
    Selective autophagy: ATG8 family proteins, LIR motifs and cargo receptors
    J. Mol. Biol. 2020; 432:80-103
    Google Scholar
    ). In this system, we determined the recruitment of a fluorescence-labeled ATG8 family member LC3 to the PolyQ-huntingtin (HTT) inclusion bodies (IBs), which contain multiple properties of protein aggregates and have been extensively investigated for aggrephagy (Figure 1A). Similar to the autophagy receptor P62 (Bjørkøy et al., 2005
    8.
    Bjørkøy, G. ∙ Lamark, T. ∙ Brech, A. ...
    p62/SQSTM1 forms protein aggregates degraded by autophagy and has a protective effect on huntingtin-induced cell death
    J. Cell Biol. 2005; 171:603-614
    Google Scholar
    ), the fluorescent LC3 was attached to the IBs (Figure 1B). In addition, IB association of the fluorescent LC3 was competed by unlabeled LC3 instead of BSA or FBS, indicating binding site specificity of LC3 on the IB (Figures 1C and 1D). To quantitatively analyze the recruitment of LC3 to the IB, we employed a pulse shape analysis (PulSA) based on flow cytometry (Ramdzan et al., 2013
    80.
    Ramdzan, Y.M. ∙ Wood, R. ∙ Hatters, D.M.
    Pulse shape analysis (PulSA) to track protein translocalization in cells by flow cytometry: applications for polyglutamine aggregation
    Methods Mol. Biol. 2013; 1017:85-93
    Google Scholar
    ) (Figures S1A and S1B). Consistently, the fluorescent LC3 was recruited to the IB, which was specifically inhibited by the unlabeled LC3 (Figures S1C and S1D). Therefore, certain components on the IB specifically associate with LC3.
    Interestingly, we observed different LC3 recruitment among IBs, indicating variable amounts of LC3-attracting components among individual IBs (Figure 1C, compare arrow with arrowhead-pointed IBs). The observation inspired us to incorporate and develop a fluorescence-activated particle sorting (FAPS) system based on flow cytometry to isolate IBs with high (H) and low (L) LC3 association from two different cell lines, a differentiated mouse neuroblastoma cell line N2A with the Q150-HTT-GFP and a human osteosarcoma cell line U2OS with Q91-HTT-mCherry (Figures 1E–1G, S1E, and S1F; Bersuker et al., 2016

    Bersuker, K. ∙ Brandeis, M. ∙ Kopito, R.R.

    ; Mitsui et al., 2002

    J. Neurosci. 2002; 22:9267-9277
    Google Scholar

Subsequently, we employed an unlabeled quantitative mass spectrometry approach to compare protein components enriched in H- and L-LC3 IBs (Figures 1I, 1J, S1H, and S1I; Tables S1 and S2). Consistent with the above immunoblot assay, P62 and NBR1 were enriched in the H-LC3 IBs (Figures 1J and S1I; Bjørkøy et al., 2005

    Interestingly, we found multiple chaperones and co-chaperones enriched in the H-LC3 IBs. These chaperones and co-chaperones were highly overlapped between the H-LC3 IBs of N2A and U2OS (Figure 1K, 11 overlap of 19 in N2A and 13 in U2OS, respectively). We determined the effects of the chaperones or co-chaperones on autophagosome association with polyQ-HTT IBs and found that nine out of the 21 analyzed chaperones or co-chaperones significantly increased the association of LC3 puncta (an indicator of autophagic membrane) with the IBs (Figures 1L, S1J, and S1K). Of the nine chaperones, six dramatically promoted lysosome-dependent polyQ-HTT degradation in a chase assay with cycloheximide (CHX) inhibition of protein synthesis employed before to determine autophagy turnover (Figures 1L and S1L–S1T; Wong et al., 2015
    112.
    Wong, P.M. ∙ Feng, Y. ∙ Wang, J. ...
    Regulation of autophagy by coordinated action of mTORC1 and protein phosphatase 2A
    Nat. Commun. 2015; 6:8048
    Google Scholar
    ). Of the six chaperones, four are chaperonin subunits (CCT1, CCT2, CCT3, and CCT6), and the other two contain HSP90AB1, a cytosolic chaperone, and HSPA9, a multi-location chaperone primarily in the mitochondria (Figure 1L, arrowhead pointed).
    We next focused on CCT2 because: (1) CCT2 was the most enriched chaperone in the mass spectrometry and had the strongest effect on promoting autophagosome association with the IB and lysosome-dependent HTT clearance (Figures 1J and 1L); (2) in the PulSA assay mentioned above (Figures S1A and S1B), knockdown (KD) of CCT2 decreased LC3 association with IBs and vice versa with the expression of exogenous CCT2, suggesting a major contribution of CCT2 to LC3 recruitment to IBs in the in vitro assay (Figures 1M and 1N); (3) in our preliminary data, IBs from glucose starvation-treated cells showed increased LC3 recruitment and mass spectrometry also indicated the enrichment of CCT2 in the IBs from glucose starvation-treated cells (data not shown); and (4) in a label-free mass spectrometry quantification, CCT2 (6-fold lower than P62 but 10-fold and 25-fold higher than NBR1 and TAX1BP1, respectively) appeared to be the highest compared with the other four chaperones (CCT1,CCT3, CCT6, and HSPA9) that associate with ATG8s (Figure 1O). Although the amount of HSP90AB1 was higher than CCT2, it did not associate with ATG8s and was not further studied (Figure S5D).

    CCT2 targets autophagic membrane to aggregates and promotes aggrephagy

    Around 10% of endogenous CCT2 (versus ∼70% of P62) localized on the IBs in N2A cells (Figure 1P). Similar to P62 (Figure 1B), the exogenously expressed CCT2 associated with IBs (Figure 2A). In addition, expression of CCT2 increased LC3 puncta with IBs (∼2.5-fold increase, Figures 2A and 2B). Similarly, the endogenous CCT2 also associated with IBs, and the amount of CCT2 around the IBs correlated with the amount of LC3 puncta association (Figures S2A and S2B). The IB-associated LC3 puncta requires LC3 lipidation, as lipidation-deficient LC3 mutant (G120A) failed to form puncta associated with IBs in the presence and absence of digitonin permeabilization to remove cytosolic components (Figures 2C and 2D). We also observed colocalization of both wild type (WT) and G120A mutant LC3 (diffused signal but not clear puncta) with the IB when co-expressed with Q103-HTT (Figure 2C), which reflects the previous results showing that the unlipidated LC3 co-aggregates with protein aggregates (Kuma et al., 2007
    50.
    Kuma, A. ∙ Matsui, M. ∙ Mizushima, N.
    LC3, an autophagosome marker, can be incorporated into protein aggregates independent of autophagy: caution in the interpretation of LC3 localization
    Autophagy. 2007; 3:323-328
    Google Scholar
    ; Shvets and Elazar, 2008
    92.
    Shvets, E. ∙ Elazar, Z.
    Autophagy-independent incorporation of GFP-LC3 into protein aggregates is dependent on its interaction with p62/SQSTM1
    Autophagy. 2008; 4:1054-1056
    Google Scholar
    ; Tanida et al., 2008
    98.
    Tanida, I. ∙ Yamaji, T. ∙ Ueno, T. ...
    Consideration about negative controls for LC3 and expression vectors for four colored fluorescent protein-LC3 negative controls
    Autophagy. 2008; 4:131-134
    Google Scholar
    ). Consistent with the requirement of LC3 lipidation, the CCT2-promoted LC3 puncta around the IB were not observed in Atg5 knockout cells (Figures 2E and 2F).
    In electron microscopy (EM), expression of CCT2 increased the recruitment of autophagic vacuoles to the IBs compared with the control (∼2-fold increase, Figures S2C and S2D). The presence of autophagic membrane-like vacuoles on IBs was also confirmed by correlative light electron microscopy (CLEM) (Figure S2E). The data indicate that CCT2 promotes autophagic membrane targeting to protein aggregates. The IB-associated LC3 puncta increased by CCT2 colocalized with FIP200/RB1CC1 and LAMP2, confirming that these puncta are autophagosomes, which can fuse with the lysosome (Figures S2F and S2G). In addition, CCT2 expression increased lysosome (labeled by LAMP2) association with the IB (Figures S2G and S2H).
    To test whether CCT2 promotes autophagic engulfment of Q103-HTT, we performed Apex2 labeling of Q103-HTT. In the EM analysis, we observed a greater number of Apex2-positive signals in the autophagic vacuoles in the cells with CCT2 expression than that in the control (Figures 2H and 2I, ∼2.5-fold increase). The autophagosome encapsulation was abolished in Atg5 KD cells or cells treated with SAR405 (Figures 2H and 2I), a class III phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase inhibitor that blocks autophagy in the early stage (Ronan et al., 2014
    83.
    Ronan, B. ∙ Flamand, O. ∙ Vescovi, L. ...
    A highly potent and selective Vps34 inhibitor alters vesicle trafficking and autophagy
    Nat. Chem. Biol. 2014; 10:1013-1019
    Google Scholar
    ). In a membrane fraction approach, CCT2 increased the amount of Q103-HTT in the autophagosome fraction (F-AG) (Figures 2J–2L, 2.5-fold and 3.9-fold before and after proteinase K digestion, respectively). Both Q103-HTT and CCT2 were protected from proteinase K digestion, indicating that they are inside the autophagosome (Figure 2L). These data together demonstrate that CCT2 promotes Q103-HTT entry into the autophagosome.
    In the chase analysis as described above (Figures S1L–S1T), expression of CCT2 enhanced Q103-HTT degradation, which was blocked by the lysosome inhibitor bafilomycin A1 in U2OS, N2A, and the primary cultured striatal neuron (Figures S2I–S2N). In a Huntington’s disease mice with polyQ (Q140) knockin (Menalled et al., 2003

    Google Scholar
    ), abolished the effect of CCT2 on Q103-HTT degradation, confirming the notion that CCT2 regulates the clearance of Q103-HTT via autophagy (Figures 2N and 2O).
    It has been shown that CHX inhibits starvation-induced autophagy via activation of mTORC1. Inhibition of mTORC1 counteracts the inhibitory effect (Watanabe-Asano et al., 2014

    Watanabe-Asano, T. ∙ Kuma, A. ∙ Mizushima, N.

Imaging assays based on analyzing IBs also confirmed the enhancing effect of CCT2 on protein aggregate clearance (Figures S5J and S5K).

In support of the notion, proteomic studies by other groups also detected CCT2 as a component of the autophagosome (Dengjel et al., 2012

Knockdown of CCT2 or two other components of TRiC, CCT4 or CCT5, did not obviously affect starvation-induced autophagy in the cell lines used in our study, as revealed by LC3 lipidation and the tandem fluorescence LC3 assay, nor did the expression of CCT2 (Figures S4A–S4F), suggesting that, in our experiments, the effect of CCT2 on Q103-HTT degradation may not attribute to autophagy regulation as a whole.     CCT2 binds to ATG8s via non-classical LC3-interaction region motifs

    In co-immunoprecipitation (coIP), CCT2 interacted with the six ATG8 family members with a preference for LC3C, in which the C-terminal one-third of CCT2 (D3), corresponding to part of the equatorial domain, accounts for the association (Figures 3A and 3B). An involvement of LC3C in aggrephagy was also reported by another study (Wetzel et al., 2020
    111.
    Wetzel, L. ∙ Blanchard, S. ∙ Rama, S. ...
    TECPR1 promotes aggrephagy by direct recruitment of LC3C autophagosomes to lysosomes
    Nat. Commun. 2020; 11:2993
    Google Scholar
    ).
    Three other TRiC subunits (CCT1, CCT3, and CCT6) and HSPA9, but not HSP90AB1, which promoted autophagosome association with IBs and lysosome-dependent polyQ-HTT turnover, also associated with ATG8s with a preference for LC3C (Figures S5A–S5E). HSPA9 is primarily a mitochondrial chaperone with multiple cellular localizations (Szabadkai et al., 2006
    96.
    Szabadkai, G. ∙ Bianchi, K. ∙ Várnai, P. ...
    Chaperone-mediated coupling of endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondrial Ca2+ channels
    J. Cell Biol. 2006; 175:901-911
    Google Scholar
    ; Wadhwa et al., 2002
    106.
    Wadhwa, R. ∙ Taira, K. ∙ Kaul, S.C.
    An Hsp70 family chaperone, mortalin/mthsp70/PBP74/Grp75: what, when, and where?
    Cell Stress Chaperones. 2002; 7:309-316
    Google Scholar
    ). Its long-form, likely the cytosolic form containing the transit peptide, associated with LC3C and IBs (Figure S5E). CCT5 and CCT8, which had little effect on polyQ-HTT degradation, did not associate with LC3C (Figure S5G). The data suggest a correlation of ATG8 association with the involvement of aggrephagy among the chaperones tested.
    Further mapping of the LC3C interaction region of CCT2-D3 using synthetic peptide pull-down found that a peptide (P7) covering aa 490–519 directly interacted with the purified LC3C (Figure 3C). Interestingly, we did not find a canonical LIR motif within P7. Instead, we noticed that two triple consecutive hydrophobic residues (VLL and VIL) resemble the NDP52 CLIR-motif, which is composed of LVV and accounts for LC3C interaction (von Muhlinen et al., 2012
    105.
    von Muhlinen, N. ∙ Akutsu, M. ∙ Ravenhill, B.J. ...
    LC3C, bound selectively by a noncanonical LIR motif in NDP52, is required for antibacterial autophagy
    Mol. Cell. 2012; 48:329-342
    Google Scholar
    ). Mutation of VLL and VIL abolished the binding of P7 to LC3C (Figure 3C), indicating that these two triple-residue motifs contribute to LC3C interaction. Requirement of the motifs for LC3C association was confirmed by coIP analysis in which mutation of either VLL or VIL rendered CCT2 deficient of association with LC3C (Figure 3D). In an in vitro pull-down assay, the WT CCT2 directly interacted with LC3C, which was abolished by the mutation of VLL and VIL (Figure 3E). We termed the VLL and VIL on P7 as the V-LC3-interacting region (VLIR) motif. We also examined the association with Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor-associated protein (GABARAP) and GABARAPL1 (GL1), two ATG8 family members which also strongly associate with CCT2 (Figure 3A). Similarly, in peptide pull-down and coIP, the two ATG8 family members directly interacted with P7 and associated with CCT2 in a VLIR-dependent manner (Figures S5H and S5I). Therefore, two VLIR motifs in CCT2 account for the interaction with LC3C, GABARAP, and GL1.
    Noticeably, the double VLIR-motif mutant (mVL(I)L) of CCT2 failed to promote autophagic membrane association with IBs, nor did it rescue the defect of digitonin-insoluble Q103-HTT aggregate clearance caused by CCT2 depletion (Figures 3F–3I). The dependence of VLIR on protein aggregate clearance was also confirmed by an imaging assay in which CCT2 but not the VLIR mutant promoted the clearance of protein aggregates/IBs (Figures S5J and S5K). The functional loss of the VLIR mutant may not be due to the reduction of TRiC activity because the CCT2-VLIR mutant associated with CCT4 and restored the level of α-tubulin, an indicator of TRiC activity (Grantham et al., 2006
    23.
    Grantham, J. ∙ Brackley, K.I. ∙ Willison, K.R.
    Substantial CCT activity is required for cell cycle progression and cytoskeletal organization in mammalian cells
    Exp. Cell Res. 2006; 312:2309-2324
    Google Scholar
    ), equally well with the WT CCT2 in CCT2-depleted cells (Figures S5L and S5M). Therefore, the data indicate that interacting with ATG8s is essential for CCT2 to promote autophagic membrane targeting and aggregate degradation.
    The second part of CCT2 VLIR (VIL) is conserved in yeast (S. cerevisiae) (Figure S6A). Similar to the mammalian CCT2, the yeast Cct2 interacted with Atg8, which is dependent on VLIR, in both coIP and in vitro pull-down experiments (Figures S6B and S6C). In a GFP-cleavage assay (Klionsky et al., 2016
    46.
    Klionsky, D.J. ∙ Abdelmohsen, K. ∙ Abe, A. ...
    Guidelines for the use and interpretation of assays for monitoring autophagy
    Autophagy. 2016; 12:1-222
    Google Scholar
    ), Cct2 expression instead of the VLIR-mutant promoted vacuole targeting of polyQ-HTT-GFP (Figures S6D and S6E). The data together indicate that the aggrephagy function of CCT2 is conserved between mammals and yeast.
    Two CCT2 point mutations (T400P and R516H) were reported to cause leber congenital amaurosis (LCA), a hereditary congenital retinopathy with severe macular degeneration (Minegishi et al., 2016
    65.
    Minegishi, Y. ∙ Sheng, X. ∙ Yoshitake, K. ...
    CCT2 mutations evoke Leber congenital amaurosis due to chaperone complex instability
    Sci. Rep. 2016; 6:33742
    Google Scholar
    ). Although a moderate compromise of TRiC function was proposed, the two mutants were still able to largely restore the level of α-tubulin after CCT2-depletion compared with WT CCT2 (Figure S5M). Instead, association with LC3C was dramatically decreased in the two mutants compared with WT CCT2, and consequently, the mutants were defective in promoting the recruitment of autophagic membrane to the IBs and Q103-HTT degradation (Figures 3J–3O). The mutants also failed to be degraded via the lysosome compared with the WT CCT2 in the CHX chase assay, indicating that they lost the character of the autophagy receptor (Figure 3N). The R516H localizes adjacent to the VIL motif (Figure 3J). Therefore, it may affect VIL interaction with LC3C. How T400P affects LC3C association is explored below (Figure S7). Although pending further evidence, the data implies that deficiency of CCT2-mediated aggrephagy may be related to retinopathy.

    CCT2 associates with aggregation-prone proteins but not ubiquitin

    CCT2 co-precipitated with the aggregation-prone proteins the turnover of which was regulated by CCT2 as shown above (Figures 4A–4C). This is consistent with the data that CCT2 associates with IBs of polyQ-HTT and the aggregates of Tau mutant protein (Figures 2A and S3A). The CCT2 apical domain is responsible for binding to polyQ-HTT (Figure 4D), which echoes the previous finding that the apical domain of chaperonin subunits binds to misfolded/unfolded substrates (Lopez et al., 2015
    60.
    Lopez, T. ∙ Dalton, K. ∙ Frydman, J.
    The mechanism and function of Group II chaperonins
    J. Mol. Biol. 2015; 427:2919-2930
    Google Scholar
    ). The data indicate that, as a chaperone protein, CCT2 interacts with aggregation-prone proteins via its intrinsic ability to bind misfolded/unfolded proteins during aggrephagy.
    In contrast to P62, CCT2 did not co-precipitate with polyubiquitin synthesized in vitro or from the cell lysates (Figures 4E and 4F). In addition, CCT2 associated with polyQ-HTT in the IB irrespective of cargo ubiquitination, as the K-R mutant of polyQ-HTT showed a similar interaction signal with the WT counterpart in the Duolink proximity ligation assay (PLA) (Figures 4G and 4H). Consistently, CCT2 expression promoted the lysosome-dependent clearance of polyQ-HTT K-R mutant equally well with the WT counterpart (Figures 4I–4K). Therefore, it is likely that CCT2 may associate with aggregation-prone proteins and promote their clearance independent of substrate ubiquitination.

    CCT2 acts independently of known pathways of degrading aggregation-prone proteins

    Our mass spectrometry data found that the known ubiquitin-binding receptors P62, NBR1, and TAX1BP1 were enriched in IBs with high LC3 association (Figure 1J). To understand the relationship between CCT2 and these ubiquitin-binding receptors in aggrephagy, we determined CCT2-LC3 association, autophagic membrane recruitment, and Q103-HTT autophagic degradation in cells triply depleted of P62, NBR1, and TAX1BP1. Although we noticed a compromise of Q103-HTT degradation in the triple receptor-depleted cells without exogenous CCT2 expression (Figure 5C), deficiency of the three receptors did not affect CCT2-LC3C association, CCT2-promoted autophagic membrane recruitment to IBs, and CCT2-enhanced Q103-HTT clearance (Figures 5A–5D and S5N). The data indicate that CCT2 acts independent of the three ubiquitin-binding receptors in regulating aggrephagy.
    CMA was also reported to regulate the clearance of soluble form of aggregation-prone proteins (Kaushik and Cuervo, 2018
    39.
    Kaushik, S. ∙ Cuervo, A.M.
    The coming of age of chaperone-mediated autophagy
    Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2018; 19:365-381
    Google Scholar
    ; Lamark and Johansen, 2012
    51.
    Lamark, T. ∙ Johansen, T.
    Aggrephagy: selective disposal of protein aggregates by macroautophagy
    Int. J. Cell Biol. 2012; 2012:736905
    Google Scholar
    ; Qi et al., 2012
    79.
    Qi, L. ∙ Zhang, X.D. ∙ Wu, J.C. ...
    The role of chaperone-mediated autophagy in huntingtin degradation
    PLoS One. 2012; 7:e46834
    Google Scholar
    ). Depletion of HSC70, the key chaperone receptor recognizing the KFERQ-motif of the cargoes (Chiang et al., 1989
    11.
    Chiang, H.L. ∙ Terlecky, S.R. ∙ Plant, C.P. ...
    A role for a 70-kilodalton heat shock protein in lysosomal degradation of intracellular proteins
    Science. 1989; 246:382-385
    Google Scholar
    ), did not affect the association of CCT2 with LC3C (Figure S5N); nor did it compromise the CCT2-promoted autophagic membrane with IBs and lysosome-dependent clearance of Q103-HTT (Figures 5E–5H). Together, the data indicate that CCT2 acts independently of multiple ubiquitin-binding receptors and CMA.

    CCT2 promotes the clearance of protein condensates with little liquidity

    Liquid-liquid phase separation was shown as a transition stage before aggregation-prone proteins form solid protein aggregates (Babinchak and Surewicz, 2020

The ubiquitin-binding receptors select cargoes with liquidity, whereas CCT2 prefers those with little liquidity in aggrephagy.
    To explore why CCT2 preferentially enhances the clearance of FUS condensates with little liquidity, we produced granules of liquid-liquid phase separation and solid aggregates of FUS (P525L) using a previous approach (Figures 6S and 6T; Hofweber et al., 2018

    ). In a protein recruitment assay, the CCT2 protein preferentially associated with solid aggregates compared with liquid granules in vitro (Figure 6U). Therefore, the data suggest that CCT2 interacts with protein condensates with little liquidity and promotes their autophagic clearance.

    CCT2 functions independently of the chaperonin TRiC in aggrephagy

    It has been shown that the proper function of TRiC requires all subunits (Gestaut et al., 2019
    21.
    Gestaut, D. ∙ Limatola, A. ∙ Joachimiak, L. ...
    The ATP-powered gymnastics of TRiC/CCT: an asymmetric protein folding machine with a symmetric origin story
    Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2019; 55:50-58
    Google Scholar
    ; Jin et al., 2019
    36.
    Jin, M. ∙ Liu, C. ∙ Han, W. ...
    TRiC/CCT chaperonin: structure and function
    Subcell. Biochem. 2019; 93:625-654
    Google Scholar
    ). In the TRiC, CCT4 and CCT5 are two neighbors of CCT2 (Gestaut et al., 2019
    21.
    Gestaut, D. ∙ Limatola, A. ∙ Joachimiak, L. ...
    The ATP-powered gymnastics of TRiC/CCT: an asymmetric protein folding machine with a symmetric origin story
    Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2019; 55:50-58
    Google Scholar
    ; Jin et al., 2019
    36.
    Jin, M. ∙ Liu, C. ∙ Han, W. ...
    TRiC/CCT chaperonin: structure and function
    Subcell. Biochem. 2019; 93:625-654
    Google Scholar
    ). To determine the involvement of TRiC complex formation in CCT2-regulated aggrephagy, we depleted CCT4 and CCT5, respectively, to disrupt the TRiC complex, which was confirmed by a reduction of α-tubulin after CCT4 or CCT5 RNAi (Figure S7A). CCT2 expression increased autophagic membrane association with IBs similarly in control, CCT4 KD, and CCT5 KD cells (Figures 7A, S7B, and S7C). Consistently, CCT2 expression promoted lysosome-dependent Q103-HTT degradation in control and CCT4 or CCT5 KD cells (Figures 7B, 7C, S7D, and S7E). The data indicate that CCT2 regulates aggrephagy independent of the integrity of the TRiC complex.
    To determine the status of CCT2 in mediating aggrephagy, we analyzed the association between CCT2 and TRiC subunits in the absence and presence of Q103-HTT using a Duolink PLA assay. Interestingly, Q103-HTT expression inhibited the association between CCT2 and TRiC subunits, suggesting that accumulation of the aggregation-prone protein affects partition of CCT2 in the TRiC (Figures 7D and 7E). To confirm, we incubated cell lysates, in which majority of CCT2 existed in the form of TRiC complex, with Q45-CFP (1.6 μM) with a comparable concentration of Q103-HTT in the cytosol in our experiments (1.5–2.0 μM, data not shown) (Figure 7F). In gel-filtration, Q45-CFP protein increased CCT2 in the ∼44-KD monomer fraction by ∼3.5-fold compared with CFP (Figure 7G, from 3.7% to 16.3% of total CCT2 in the monomer fraction). Several other CCT subunits also appeared to increase in the non-TRiC complex fractions, suggesting partial disruption of TRiC by polyQ-HTT (Figure 7G). Together, the data indicate that accumulation of polyQ-HTT promotes the monomer form of CCT2 and may affect the integrity of the TRiC complex.
    The VLIR motif locates in the equatorial domain of CCT2 and is buried into the TRiC complex (Knowlton et al., 2021
    47.
    Knowlton, J.J. ∙ Gestaut, D. ∙ Ma, B. ...
    Structural and functional dissection of reovirus capsid folding and assembly by the prefoldin-TRiC/CCT chaperone network
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2021; 118
    e2018127118
    Google Scholar
    ; Figure 7H). It is likely that via dissociating from the TRiC complex, the VLIR motif is exposed and can associate with ATG8s. The notion is confirmed by a pull-down experiment in which CCT2 in the monomer instead of in the TRiC complex fraction interacted with LC3C (Figure 7I). In addition, the exogenously expressed CCT2 which promoted aggrephagy were primarily monomeric (Figure 7J). Co-expression of other TRiC subunits decreased monomeric CCT2 by forming the TRiC complex and, therefore, compromised the CCT2 association with LC3C, as well as the CCT2 promoted autophagic membrane recruitment to IBs and Q103-HTT degradation (Figures 7J–7N, S7F, and S7G). We also found that in addition to CCT2, the rest of the TRiC subunits were able to associate with IBs (Figure 7K), which is consistent with previous studies showing that the TRiC complex and subunits localize to protein aggregates (Behrends et al., 2006
    6.
    Behrends, C. ∙ Langer, C.A. ∙ Boteva, R. ...
    Chaperonin TRiC promotes the assembly of polyQ expansion proteins into nontoxic oligomers
    Mol. Cell. 2006; 23:887-897
    Google Scholar
    ; Shahmoradian et al., 2013
    90.
    Shahmoradian, S.H. ∙ Galaz-Montoya, J.G. ∙ Schmid, M.F. ...
    TRiC's tricks inhibit huntingtin aggregation
    Elife. 2013; 2:e00710
    Google Scholar
    ; Tam et al., 2006
    97.
    Tam, S. ∙ Geller, R. ∙ Spiess, C. ...
    The chaperonin TRiC controls polyglutamine aggregation and toxicity through subunit-specific interactions
    Nat. Cell Biol. 2006; 8:1155-1162
    Google Scholar
    ). Importantly, the T400P mutation enhanced CCT2 association with CCT4 and partition into the TRiC complex (Figures S7H and S7I). In addition, the mutation compromised the release of CCT2 (T400P) from the TRiC complex caused by polyQ-HTT, and, therefore, decreased the ability of CCT2 to associate with LC3 and to promote aggrephagy as shown above (Figure S7I).
    Together, the data indicate a scenario of CCT2 dissociation from the TRiC complex induced by excessive aggregation-prone proteins as a switch of chaperonin function from protein folding to autophagy. The monomeric CCT2 is able to associate with ATG8s and, therefore, acts as an autophagy receptor to promote the degradation of protein aggregates (Figure 7O).

    Discussion

    It has been well-recognized that chaperones primarily function to assist protein folding (Kim et al., 2013
    42.
    Kim, Y.E. ∙ Hipp, M.S. ∙ Bracher, A. ...
    Molecular chaperone functions in protein folding and proteostasis
    Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2013; 82:323-355
    Google Scholar
    ). The current work identifies the chaperonin subunit CCT2 as an aggrephagy receptor which facilitates the clearance of aggregation-prone proteins. Therefore, the study implies a double defense mechanism of the chaperonin TRiC for proteostasis, which is likely regulated through a functional switch. It is plausible that in the presence of misfolded proteins, TRiC performs its conventional function to refold these proteins and prevent aggregation as the first line of defense. When excessive misfolded proteins accumulate to form protein aggregates, which is an indication of chaperone system exhaustion, a fraction of the TRiC subunit CCT2 becomes monomeric and switches its function to autophagy receptor as a second line of defense to maintain proteostasis (Figure 7O).
    An induced interaction with ATG8s likely accounts for the switch of CCT2 function. The VLIR motifs are buried in the TRiC complex under steady states (Figure 7H). Excessive aggregation-prone protein polyQ-HTT induced the formation of CCT2 monomer, exposing the VLIR motifs and enabling it to interact with ATG8 family members (Figures 7G and 7I). The model is supported by the T400P mutation identified in LCA, which decreases CCT2 monomer by enhancing CCT2 distribution in the TRiC complex and, therefore, compromises ATG8s association and aggrephagy (Figures 3K–3M, S7H, and S7I). It is pending to know how the T400P mutation increases CCT2 partition into the TRiC complex. Based on the structure of TRiC, threonine 400 locates on the α-helix essential for ATP hydrolysis (Knowlton et al., 2021
    47.
    Knowlton, J.J. ∙ Gestaut, D. ∙ Ma, B. ...
    Structural and functional dissection of reovirus capsid folding and assembly by the prefoldin-TRiC/CCT chaperone network
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2021; 118
    e2018127118
    Google Scholar
    ). The T400P mutation may disrupt the α-helix and affect ATP hydrolysis which consequently prolongs the closed conformation of the TRiC complex. It has been proposed that the TRiC complex may be stabilized in the closed state due to less dynamics and more interaction among eight helical protrusions at the lid of the cavity (Kanzaki et al., 2008
    38.
    Kanzaki, T. ∙ Iizuka, R. ∙ Takahashi, K. ...
    Sequential action of ATP-dependent subunit conformational change and interaction between helical protrusions in the closure of the built-in lid of group II chaperonins
    J. Biol. Chem. 2008; 283:34773-34784
    Google Scholar
    ; Zang et al., 2016
    120.
    Zang, Y. ∙ Jin, M. ∙ Wang, H. ...
    Staggered ATP binding mechanism of eukaryotic chaperonin TRiC (CCT) revealed through high-resolution cryo-EM
    Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2016; 23:1083-1091
    Google Scholar
    ). Therefore, the T400P mutation may stabilize the TRiC by affecting ATP hydrolysis and prolonging the time of closed conformation.
    The study identifies CCT2 as an autophagy receptor. CCT2 interacts with ATG8s and aggregation-prone proteins through a non-classical VLIR motif in the equatorial domain and the apical domain, respectively (Figures 3 and 4). Therefore, CCT2 promotes autophagic membrane targeting to protein aggregates and clearance of aggregation-prone proteins, the process of which is independent of the ubiquitin-binding receptors (P62, NBR1, and TAX1BP1) and CMA (Figure 5). In contrast to the ubiquitin-binding autophagy receptors, CCT2 does not bind to poly-ubiquitins (Figures 4D and 4E). Therefore, the CCT2-mediated aggrephagy represents a way of protein aggregates clearance different from that of the ubiquitin-binding autophagy receptors. It has been shown that, in selective autophagy, autophagy receptors (e.g., NDP52 and Optineurin) recruit ULK1 complex to enhance autophagosome biogenesis in situ (Lazarou et al., 2015
    52.
    Lazarou, M. ∙ Sliter, D.A. ∙ Kane, L.A. ...
    The ubiquitin kinase PINK1 recruits autophagy receptors to induce mitophagy
    Nature. 2015; 524:309-314
    Google Scholar
    ). In addition, the phosphatidylinositol-3 phosphate binding protein ALFY also activates autophagic membrane synthesis on the aggregate via recruiting ATG5, a key component of the E3 in the ubiquitin-like conjugation system required for ATG8 lipidation (Filimonenko et al., 2010
    17.
    Filimonenko, M. ∙ Isakson, P. ∙ Finley, K.D. ...
    The selective macroautophagic degradation of aggregated proteins requires the PI3P-binding protein Alfy
    Mol. Cell. 2010; 38:265-279
    Google Scholar
    ). Furthermore, multiple post-translational modifications regulate the activity of autophagy receptors (Gubas and Dikic, 2021
    25.
    Gubas, A. ∙ Dikic, I.
    A guide to the regulation of selective autophagy receptors
    FEBS J. 2021; 289:75-89
    Google Scholar
    ). In the future, it would be interesting to know whether CCT2 is able to recruit upstream autophagic factors or is regulated by post-translational modifications during aggrephagy.
    Although several studies found that liquidity is a prerequisite for autophagy-mediated clearance of protein condensates (Agudo-Canalejo et al., 2021
    1.
    Agudo-Canalejo, J. ∙ Schultz, S.W. ∙ Chino, H. ...
    Wetting regulates autophagy of phase-separated compartments and the cytosol
    Nature. 2021; 591:142-146
    Google Scholar
    ; Yamasaki et al., 2020
    116.
    Yamasaki, A. ∙ Alam, J.M. ∙ Noshiro, D. ...
    Liquidity is a critical determinant for selective autophagy of protein condensates
    Mol. Cell. 2020; 77:1163-1175.e9
    Google Scholar
    ; Zhang et al., 2018
    122.
    Zhang, G. ∙ Wang, Z. ∙ Du, Z. ...
    mTOR regulates phase separation of PGL granules to modulate their autophagic degradation
    Cell. 2018; 174:1492-1506.e22
    e1422
    Google Scholar
    ), CCT2 promotes the degradation of protein granules with little liquidity (Figure 6). The selectivity toward little liquidity could be partially explained by the fact that CCT2 associates with solid protein aggregates rather than granules of liquid-liquid phase separation (Figure 6U). Why does CCT2 associate with solid aggregates? It has been shown that solid protein aggregates contain misfolded proteins as well as fibers with conformation of β sheets (Eisenberg and Jucker, 2012
    16.
    Eisenberg, D. ∙ Jucker, M.
    The amyloid state of proteins in human diseases
    Cell. 2012; 148:1188-1203
    Google Scholar
    ; Vendruscolo, 2012
    104.
    Vendruscolo, M.
    Proteome folding and aggregation
    Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2012; 22:138-143
    Google Scholar
    ). As a chaperone subunit, CCT2 has the intrinsic propensity to bind unfolded or misfolded proteins (Gestaut et al., 2019
    21.
    Gestaut, D. ∙ Limatola, A. ∙ Joachimiak, L. ...
    The ATP-powered gymnastics of TRiC/CCT: an asymmetric protein folding machine with a symmetric origin story
    Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2019; 55:50-58
    Google Scholar
    ; Jin et al., 2019
    36.
    Jin, M. ∙ Liu, C. ∙ Han, W. ...
    TRiC/CCT chaperonin: structure and function
    Subcell. Biochem. 2019; 93:625-654
    Google Scholar
    ). In addition, the chaperonin TRiC has been shown to preferentially associate with aggregation-prone proteins with β sheets conformation (Yam et al., 2008
    115.
    Yam, A.Y. ∙ Xia, Y. ∙ Lin, H.T. ...
    Defining the TRiC/CCT interactome links chaperonin function to stabilization of newly made proteins with complex topologies
    Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2008; 15:1255-1262
    Google Scholar
    ). Therefore, the conformation of proteins in the solid aggregates may contribute to CCT2 association.
    The ubiquitin-binding receptors P62 and NBR1 were shown to drive phase separation of cargoes with poly-ubiquitin chain, the process of which was proposed to facilitate autophagic clearance (Noda et al., 2020
    72.
    Noda, N.N. ∙ Wang, Z. ∙ Zhang, H.
    Liquid-liquid phase separation in autophagy
    J. Cell Biol. 2020; 219
    e202004062
    Google Scholar
    ; Sun et al., 2018
    95.
    Sun, D. ∙ Wu, R. ∙ Zheng, J. ...
    Polyubiquitin chain-induced p62 phase separation drives autophagic cargo segregation
    Cell Res. 2018; 28:405-415
    Google Scholar
    , 2020
    94.
    Sun, D. ∙ Wu, R. ∙ Li, P. ...
    Phase separation in regulation of aggrephagy
    J. Mol. Biol. 2020; 432:160-169
    Google Scholar
    ; Turco et al., 2021
    100.
    Turco, E. ∙ Savova, A. ∙ Gere, F. ...
    Reconstitution defines the roles of p62, NBR1 and TAX1BP1 in ubiquitin condensate formation and autophagy initiation
    Nat. Commun. 2021; 12:5212
    Google Scholar
    ; Zaffagnini et al., 2018
    119.
    Zaffagnini, G. ∙ Savova, A. ∙ Danieli, A. ...
    p62 filaments capture and present ubiquitinated cargos for autophagy
    EMBO J. 2018; 37:e98308
    Google Scholar
    ). In our data, P62, NBR1, and TAX1BP1 are involved in the turnover of FUS (P525L) condensates with liquidity (Figures 6K–6P). These data support the notion that these ubiquitin-binding receptors are primarily responsible for the autophagic degradation of protein condensates with liquidity. Together, these pieces of evidence indicate that CCT2 and the ubiquitin-binding receptors act complementarily to clear different types of protein condensates in the process of aggrephagy.
    Our data indicate that the LCA-causing mutations of CCT2 affects aggrephagy, suggesting a link between aggrephagy deficiency and retinopathy. The retina is one of the highest oxygen-consuming tissues by exposing to a microenvironment of abundant photosensitizers, visible light exposure and high energy demands. Oxidative damage has been known as a major cause of age-related macular degeneration (Jarrett and Boulton, 2012
    35.
    Jarrett, S.G. ∙ Boulton, M.E.
    Consequences of oxidative stress in age-related macular degeneration
    Mol. Aspects Med. 2012; 33:399-417
    Google Scholar
    ). Considering massive oxidative stress causes protein damage, misfolding, and aggregation, the macular cells may be easily subjected to proteotoxic stress and more liable to aggrephagy deficiency. A correlation between protein aggregate accumulation and LCA has been suggested by studies on the chaperone interacting protein AIPL1. It was shown that several of the LCA-causing AIPL1 mutants led to the accumulation of NUB1 aggregates (Hidalgo-de-Quintana et al., 2008
    28.
    Hidalgo-de-Quintana, J. ∙ Evans, R.J. ∙ Cheetham, M.E. ...
    The Leber congenital amaurosis protein AIPL1 functions as part of a chaperone heterocomplex
    Invest. Ophthalmol. Vis. Sci. 2008; 49:2878-2887
    Google Scholar
    ; van der Spuy and Cheetham, 2004
    102.
    van der Spuy, J. ∙ Cheetham, M.E.
    The Leber congenital amaurosis protein AIPL1 modulates the nuclear translocation of NUB1 and suppresses inclusion formation by NUB1 fragments
    J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279:48038-48047
    Google Scholar
    ). In the future, it will be important to know whether protein aggregation is a major cause of LCA and how CCT2-mediated aggrephagy contributes to proteostasis maintenance in retina cells. Also, considering the CCT2 mutations identified in LCA affect aggrephagy, which is essential for neuronal cell proteostasis, it would be interesting to know whether LCA patients with the CCT2 mutations have neurodegenerative disorders.
    Accumulating evidence indicates that selective autophagy is compromised in neurodegeneration and its restoration has beneficial effects (Dikic and Elazar, 2018
    15.
    Dikic, I. ∙ Elazar, Z.
    Mechanism and medical implications of mammalian autophagy
    Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2018; 19:349-364
    Google Scholar
    ; Menzies et al., 2015
    64.
    Menzies, F.M. ∙ Fleming, A. ∙ Rubinsztein, D.C.
    Compromised autophagy and neurodegenerative diseases
    Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 2015; 16:345-357
    Google Scholar
    ; Nixon, 2013
    71.
    Nixon, R.A.
    The role of autophagy in neurodegenerative disease
    Nat. Med. 2013; 19:983-997
    Google Scholar
    ; Scrivo et al., 2018
    89.
    Scrivo, A. ∙ Bourdenx, M. ∙ Pampliega, O. ...
    Selective autophagy as a potential therapeutic target for neurodegenerative disorders
    Lancet Neurol. 2018; 17:802-815
    Google Scholar
    ). The notion was confirmed in principle by a recent work showing that small molecules selectively bridging the mutant HTT to autophagy degradation alleviates the neurodegenerative phenotype in a mouse model of Huntington’s disease (Li et al., 2019
    54.
    Li, Z. ∙ Wang, C. ∙ Wang, Z. ...
    Allele-selective lowering of mutant HTT protein by HTT–LC3 linker compounds
    Nature. 2019; 575:203-209
    Google Scholar
    ). Our work identifies CCT2 as an aggrephagy receptor for selective clearance of protein aggregates. Interestingly, the protein level of CCT2 was shown to be reduced in neurodegenerative brains (Huntington disease and Alzheimer disease) (Brehme et al., 2014
    9.
    Brehme, M. ∙ Voisine, C. ∙ Rolland, T. ...
    A chaperome subnetwork safeguards proteostasis in aging and neurodegenerative disease
    Cell Rep. 2014; 9:1135-1150
    Google Scholar
    ), suggesting that insufficient CCT2 may associate with neurodegeneration. Our study partially confirms the notion in another perspective by showing that expression of CCT2 reduces the amount of endogenous polyQ-HTT in mouse striatum (Figure 2M). Therefore, restoring CCT2 level enhances toxic protein clearance and might benefit patients with neurodegeneration. The TRiC complex and subunits have been shown to relieve polyQ-HTT toxicity by preventing aggregation and formation of toxic oligomers (Behrends et al., 2006
    6.
    Behrends, C. ∙ Langer, C.A. ∙ Boteva, R. ...
    Chaperonin TRiC promotes the assembly of polyQ expansion proteins into nontoxic oligomers
    Mol. Cell. 2006; 23:887-897
    Google Scholar
    ; Tam et al., 2006
    97.
    Tam, S. ∙ Geller, R. ∙ Spiess, C. ...
    The chaperonin TRiC controls polyglutamine aggregation and toxicity through subunit-specific interactions
    Nat. Cell Biol. 2006; 8:1155-1162
    Google Scholar
    ). The double beneficial effects of protein aggregate detoxification and clearance make TRiC complex an enticing therapeutic target against neurodegeneration and other related diseases.

    Limitations of the study

    The current work suggests that multiple chaperones may be involved in regulating the autophagic clearance of protein aggregates. With a focus on CCT2, the work reveals that CCT2 acts independently of the known ubiquitin-binding receptors and specifically regulates the clearance of protein aggregates with little liquidity. In addition, the monomer formation of CCT2 regulates the switch of function between a chaperone subunit and an aggrephagy receptor. Although the current data indicate that the monomer CCT2 may be released from the chaperonin complex, they could not rule out the possibility that the newly synthesized CCT2 subunit may directly participate in aggrephagy before it assembles into the TRiC. In addition, it is still unclear how the other chaperones or subunits function in the process of aggrephagy. More work needs to be done to understand whether these chaperones or subunits act in a similar or a different mechanism with CCT2.
    It is pending to know how the large IBs are cleared by the autophagosome. Several chaperones have been shown to fragment fibrils in the IB (Gao et al., 2015
    18.
    Gao, X. ∙ Carroni, M. ∙ Nussbaum-Krammer, C. ...
    Human Hsp70 disaggregase reverses parkinson's-linked α-synuclein amyloid fibrils
    Mol. Cell. 2015; 59:781-793
    Google Scholar
    ; Nachman et al., 2020
    70.
    Nachman, E. ∙ Wentink, A.S. ∙ Madiona, K. ...
    Disassembly of Tau fibrils by the human Hsp70 disaggregation machinery generates small seeding-competent species
    J. Biol. Chem. 2020; 295:9676-9690
    Google Scholar
    ). The fragmented fibrils may fit into the size of the autophagysome (0.5–1.5 μm) and enable the piecemeal (Mizushima et al., 2002
    67.
    Mizushima, N. ∙ Ohsumi, Y. ∙ Yoshimori, T.
    Autophagosome formation in mammalian cells
    Cell Struct. Funct. 2002; 27:421-429
    Google Scholar
    ). In this case, multiple chaperones may cooperate to facilitate aggrephagy. Remarkably, HSP90AB1 was identified as a chaperone that associated with IBs abundantly and promoted aggrephagy without interacting with ATG8s (Figures 1J, 1L, and S5D), suggesting that HSP90AB1 may act in a different manner compared with CCT2. It is pending to define whether HSP90AB1 is involved in IB fragmentation or other processes that facilitate aggregate clearance. Regarding the physiological role of CCT2, although we found that CCT2 expression can reduce the amount of polyQ-HTT in mouse brain and striatum neuron, it is unclear whether CCT2 expression is able to promote the clearance of other aggregation-prone proteins in vivo. In addition, mice models with the point mutations of CCT2 causing LCA as well as mutations of the CCT2 VLIR need to be established to understand which physiological processes are affected by the loss of CCT2-mediated aggrephagy.

    Experimental model and subject details

    Cells

    HEK293T, U2OS, and N2A cells were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS at 37°C in 5% CO2. For induction of Q91- HTT-mCherry expression, U2OS HTT-Q91-mCherry cells were incubated with 1 μg/ml doxycycline for 24 h. For induction of Q150-HTT-GFP expression, N2A Q150-HTT-GFP cells were differentiated with 5 mM dbcAMP for 24 h followed by 1 μM ponasterone A for 48 h (Jana et al., 2000
    34.
    Jana, N.R. ∙ Tanaka, M. ∙ Wang, Gh ...
    Polyglutamine length-dependent interaction of Hsp40 and Hsp70 family chaperones with truncated N-terminal huntingtin: their role in suppression of aggregation and cellular toxicity
    Hum. Mol. Genet. 2000; 9:2009-2018
    Google Scholar
    ). The cells were employed for in vitro reconstitution, immunofluorescence, electron microscopy, and biochemical assays as described below. Transfection of DNA constructs was performed using PEI (Polysciences, Inc.) for HEK293T and X-tremeGENE HP (Roche) for U2OS and N2A. The siRNA transfection was performed with Lipofectamine RNAiMAX (Invitrogen) as described previously (Xiao et al., 2019
    114.
    Xiao, J. ∙ Luo, J. ∙ Hu, A. ...
    Cholesterol transport through the peroxisome-ER membrane contacts tethered by PI(4,5)P2 and extended synaptotagmins
    Sci. China Life Sci. 2019; 62:1117-1135
    Google Scholar
    ; Zhang et al., 2020
    124.
    Zhang, M. ∙ Liu, L. ∙ Lin, X. ...
    A translocation pathway for vesicle-mediated unconventional protein secretion
    Cell. 2020; 181:637-652.e15
    Google Scholar
    )
    For primary culture of mouse striatal neurons, mouse striatal neurons were dissected from newborn WT mice and incubated in 0.25% trypsin-ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (Life Technologies) for 15 min at 37°C. After washing with Hank’s Buffered Salt Solution plus 5 mM Hepes (Life Technologies), 20 mM D-glucose, and 2% fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Gibco), the neurons were mechanically dissociated in culture medium and plated on poly-D-lysine-coated glass coverslips at a density of 50,000 to 100,000 cells/cm2. Cells were grown in Neurobasal-A medium (Life Technologies) supplemented with 2% B-27 (Life Technologies) and 2 mM glutamax (Life Technologies). Cultures were maintained at 37°C in a 5% CO2-humidified incubator. Adeno-associated virus (AAV) was added to neurons at day in vitro (DIV) 3, and the chase assay was performed as described below at DIV8.

    Mice

    The Hdh140Q knock-in mice were gifts from Boxun Lu (Li et al., 2019
    54.
    Li, Z. ∙ Wang, C. ∙ Wang, Z. ...
    Allele-selective lowering of mutant HTT protein by HTT–LC3 linker compounds
    Nature. 2019; 575:203-209
    Google Scholar
    ). The generation and characterization of the Hdh140Q knock-in mice have been previously described (Menalled et al., 2003
    63.
    Menalled, L.B. ∙ Sison, J.D. ∙ Dragatsis, I. ...
    Time course of early motor and neuropathological anomalies in a knock-in mouse model of Huntington's disease with 140 CAG repeats
    J. Comp. Neurol. 2003; 465:11-26
    Google Scholar
    ). The mice were housed in ventilated cages in a temperature and light regulated room in a SPF facility and received food and water ad libitum. The mouse experiments were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committees at Tsinghua University and they were in compliance with all relevant ethical regulations. Male mice of 2-month-old were used in the study.

    Yeast

    Yeast cells were grown at 30°C in synthetic medium (SD; 0.17% yeast nitrogen base without amino acids and ammonium sulfate, 0.5% ammonium sulfate, 2% glucose, and corresponding auxotrophic amino acids and vitamins), or YPD (1% yeast extract, 2% peptone, and 2% glucose). For autophagy induction, the cells were grown to mid-log phase in corresponding selective medium, and then were subjected to starvation at 30°C in nitrogen starvation medium (SD−N; 0.17% yeast nitrogen base without amino acids and ammonium sulfate, 2% glucose) for the indicated time durations.

    Method details

    In vitro reconstitution

    The in vitro reconstitution contains steps of protein purification, fluorescence labeling, and in vitro LC3 recruitment assay. Protein purification was described before (Ge et al., 2013
    20.
    Ge, L. ∙ Melville, D. ∙ Zhang, M. ...
    The ER-Golgi intermediate compartment is a key membrane source for the LC3 lipidation step of autophagosome biogenesis
    Elife. 2013; 2:e00947
    Google Scholar
    ; Zhang et al., 2020
    124.
    Zhang, M. ∙ Liu, L. ∙ Lin, X. ...
    A translocation pathway for vesicle-mediated unconventional protein secretion
    Cell. 2020; 181:637-652.e15
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, His-tagged LC3 protein with a cysteine interaction in the N-terminus for fluorophore maleimide labeling was expressed in E.coli BL21 and purified using Nickel Sepharose (GE). The LC3 protein was labeled with Alexa Fluor 647/488 C2 maleimide (Invitrogen) according to the manual provided and subsequently gel filtrated to remove the unlabeled fluorophore. For in vitro reconstitution of LC3 recruitment to the IBs in the cell, U2OS HTT-Q91-mCherry or N2A HTT-Q150-GFP cells were plated on a coverslip (for immunofluorescence), and fluorescence-tagged PolyQ-HTT IBs were induced for 24-48 h. The cells were then treated with 40 μg/ml digitonin on ice to permeabilize the plasma membrane, incubated with 5-10 μg/ml fluorescence-labeled LC3 for 1 h at 30 °C, and fixed by 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for microscopy analysis. For in vitro reconstitution of LC3 to IB in solution, the cells with IBs were harvested and lysed in B88 (20mM HEPES (pH 7.2), 250 mM sorbitol, 150 mM potassium acetate, 5mM magnesium acetate) with 1% Triton X-100, protease inhibitors, DNase and RNase. The lysate was centrifuged at 300 xg. The pellet containing the IBs was collected and incubated with 5-10 μg/ml fluorescence-labeled LC3 for 1 h at 30 °C after which FACS was performed to analyze LC3 recruitment to IBs as further described below.

    FACS analysis, sorting of IBs and mass spectrometry-based label-free quantification

    To analyze LC3 recruitment to IBs or sort two groups of IBs (High-LC3 IB and Low-LC3 IB), U2OS HTT-Q91-mCherry or N2A HTT-Q150-GFP cells were plated in 10 cm dishes and fluorescence-tagged PolyQ-HTT IB was induced for 24-48 h as described above. The cells were harvested by centrifugation and lysed in B88 with 1% Triton X-100, protease inhibitors, DNase, and RNase by passaging through a 22G needle for 10 times. The lysate was then centrifuged at 300 xg for 10 min. The pellet containing the IBs was collected and incubated with 0.5-1 μg/ml fluorescence-labeled LC3 in B88 with protease inhibitors for 1 h at 30 °C. The reaction mixture was centrifuged at 1000 xg for 5 min and suspended in B88 with 1% Triton X-100 to wash the pellet, followed by centrifugation at 1000 xg for 5 min. Finally, the pellet was suspended in B88 with 1% Triton X-100 and FACS analysis (PulSA, BD Fortessa) or sorting (BD Influx) was performed as described previously with modifications described in figure legends (Ramdzan et al., 2013
    80.
    Ramdzan, Y.M. ∙ Wood, R. ∙ Hatters, D.M.
    Pulse shape analysis (PulSA) to track protein translocalization in cells by flow cytometry: applications for polyglutamine aggregation
    Methods Mol. Biol. 2013; 1017:85-93
    Google Scholar
    ). After sorting, the IB solutions were centrifuged at 3000 xg for 30 min, and pellet were analyzed by immunoblot or mass spectrometry in Taplin Biological Mass Spectrometry Facility at Harvard Medical School.
    To quantify the known receptors and CCT2 on IBs or in cells, N2A HTT-Q150-GFP cells were plated in 10 cm dishes and fluorescence-tagged PolyQ-HTT IB was induced for 48 h. The cells were harvested by centrifugation and lysed in HB1 buffer (20 mM HEPES-KOH, pH 7.2, 400 mM Sucrose, 1 mM EDTA) with 1% Triton X-100, protease inhibitors, DNase, and RNase by passaging through a 22G needle for 10 times. The lysate was then centrifuged at 300 xg for 10 min. The pellet containing the IBs was suspended with PBS. IBs or IB-positive cells were sorted by BD FACSAria SORP. After sorting, the IBs and cell solutions were centrifuged at 3000 xg for 30 min. Mass spectrometry analysis was performed at the Protein Chemistry and Proteomics Center at Tsinghua University. In brief, the IB proteins (IB group) and total cell proteins (cell group) were resolved in SDS-PAGE and stained by Simply Blue (Invitrogen). The lanes were excised from the gel, reduced, alkylated, and digested with trypsin overnight. The resulting tryptic peptides were analyzed using an UltiMate 3000 RSLCnano System (Thermo Scientific, USA) which was directly interfaced with a Thermo Orbitrap Fusion Lumos mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The RAW files were searched against the Mouse Proteome (Uniprot) database using an in-house Proteome Discoverer 2.3 searching algorithm. The peak area was used for protein abundance comparison between the IB group and the cell group. The iBAQ value calculated by Maxquant was used to estimate the protein content in IB group.

    CHX chase assay

    Cells were transfected with indicated plasmids. After transfection for the indicated times (in Figure legends), cells were treated with 50 μg/ml CHX, with or without 0.5 μg/ml Bafilomycin A1 as indicated and were collected at each indicated time point for immunoblot analysis. For the insoluble Q103-HTT detection, cells were permeabilized with 40 μg/ml of digitonin diluted in PBS on ice for 5 min and washed with PBS before being collected for immunoblot analysis.

    Q140 Mice and AAV injection

    AAV with CCT2 or mCherry gene cassette was delivered to the striatum. Briefly, Hdh140Q mice were anesthetized by an i.p. injection with avertin and immobilized on rodent stereotaxic frames. A burr hole was used to perforate the skull, and the AAVs (400nl per injection spot, 5 x1012 vg/ml) were injected into the striatum using a 10 μl syringe at a rate of 50 nl/min. The injection coordinates were Anterior/Posterior (AP) +0.9mm, Medial/Lateral (ML) +/- 1.8 mm from the bregma, and Dorsal/Ventral (DV) -2.7 mm from the dura. Striatal tissues of Hdh140Q mice were carefully removed for immunoblot analyses at 2 months post AAV injection.

    The His-T7-LC3C/GABARAP/GABARAPL1, His-CFP/Q45-CFP, His-mRuby2/mRuby2-CCT2, and MBP-TEV-GFP-FUS P525L proteins were purified using Ni sepharose (GE Healthcare), and the GST, GST-HA-CCT2s, and GST-P62 proteins were purified using Glutathione beads as described before (Zhang et al., 2020
